_prev_prog_2.Description: The Hanover Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant uses chlorine gas for disinfection of treated wastewater.  The gas is received in one-ton containers and dissoved into water using vacuum feed chlorination with leak detection.  A gas detector and alarm system is connected to an automatic telephone dialer.  Two people unload a delivery truck with a crane hoist, an approved lifting device.  Empty chlorine containers are exchanged by a team of two operators.  Self-contained breathing apparatus is available on-site.  The Adam County Defensive Hazardous Materials Response Team is the delegated first-responder and uses an emergency response plan developed by the Adams County LEPC as a result of SARA III and EPCRA reporting.  Additionally, supported is provided by the York County Hazardous Response Team, if needed.  The release risk management program in place at the facility ensures that all equipment, including process and safety equipment, is in excellent working condition.  A call-out list assures that there is round-the-clock coverage of operations of the facility.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Borough of Hanover owns and operates a Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP). The plant service area includes Hanover Borough and a portion of Penn Township in York County, and a portion of McSherrystown Borough and Conewago Township in Adams County, Pennsylvania.  The WWTP, located at the end of O'Brien Lane in Conewego Township, is permitted for an Annual Average Flow of 5.6 million gallons per day of wastewater and discharges to the South Branch Conewego Creek under NPDES Permit No. PA0026875.  Wastewater treatment processes include grit and screenings removal, primary clarification, activated sludge treatment process, final clarification, denitrification filters, disinfection, and de-chlorination.  Biosolids are stabilized in anaerobic digesters, dewatered, and utilized for agricultural purposes through land application.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.



The WWTP includes a disinfection system comprised of a chlorine container room, which contains two (2) one-ton containers of chlorine liquefied under pressure, a chlorinator, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  Up to six (6) one-ton containers may be on-site simultaneously.  The chlorinator system extracts chlorine gas from the storage containers through vacuum regulators and dissolves this gas in water to form a disinfection solution that is used to kill pathogenic bacteria and microorganisms in the treated wastewater effluent prior to its discharge into the receiving stream. Treatment plant operators regularly check the chlorinator room and its equipment, inventorying the rate of chlorine use and adjusting the rate as necessary.  The maximum intended inventory for planning purposes is 12,000 pounds.



To improve the water quality of the effluent discharged to the receiving stream, the WWTP utilizes sulfur dioxide gas, another regulated substance, to de-chlorinate its effluent through a proce

ce of gas detectors.



No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at this facility since the WWTP went into service in 1986.  No accidental releases of sulfur dioxide have occurred at this facility since the WWTP started to use sulfur dioxide in March 1999.  Therefore, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide within the 5-year review period stipulated for this RMP.



The facility has an emergency response program that has been reviewed and coordinated by the Adams County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.  The operation and response procedures are reviewed and updated on an annual basis by the Adams County LEPC.  The Adams County Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) team is the designated first-responder in the event of a chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak incident.  The Adams County HAZMAT team is trained only at the Technician Level and, therefore, is not state certified; however, they can provide limited support for leak containment.  Under a mutual aid agreement between Adams County and York County, the York County HAZMAT team will provide additional support for chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak.  The York County HAZMAT team is state certified and undergoes extensive training in dealing with a variety of hazardous material incidents, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas leaks. 



Recommendations to improve safety were made following a June 25, 2013 inspection of the chlorination and dechlorination facilities by the Borough's Consulting Engineer.  These recommendations include routine review, and updating as necessary, of the written emergency standard operating procedures (SOPs), continued implementation of the operator training program, and increased documentation of routine functions related to the performance of the two (2) regulated processes.
